raw_text:
Humanoid robot learns how to run
 
 Car-maker Honda's humanoid robot Asimo has just got faster and smarter.
 
 The Japanese firm is a leader in developing two-legged robots and the new, improved Asimo (Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility) can now run, find his way around obstacles as well as interact with people. Eventually Asimo could find gainful employment in homes and offices. "The aim is to develop a robot that can help people in their daily lives," said a Honda spokesman.
 
 To get the robot running for the first time was not an easy process as it involved Asimo making an accurate leap and absorbing the impact of landing without slipping or spinning. The "run" he is now capable of is perhaps not quite up to Olympic star Kelly Holmes' standard. At 3km/h, it is closer to a leisurely jog. Its makers claim that it is almost four times as fast as Sony's Qrio, which became the first robot to run last year. The criteria for running robots is defined by engineers as having both feet off the ground between strides. Asimo has improved in other ways too, increasing his walking speed, from 1.6km/h to 2.5km, growing 10cm to 130cm and putting on 2kg in weight. While he may not quite be ready for yoga, he does have more freedom of movement, being able to twist his hips and bend his wrists, thumbs and neck.
 
 Asimo has already made his mark on the international robot scene and in November was inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame. He has wowed audiences around the world with his ability to walk upstairs, recognise faces and come when beckoned. In August 2003 he even attended a state dinner in the Czech Republic, travelling with the Japanese prime minister as a goodwill envoy. He is one of a handful of robots used by tech firms to trumpet their technological advances. Technology developed for Asimo could be used in the automobile industry as electronics increasingly take over from mechanics in car design. For the moment Asimo's biggest role is an entertainer and the audience gathered to see his first public run greeted his slightly comical gait with amusement, according to reports. Robots can fulfil serious functions in society and the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe predicts that the worldwide market for industrial robots will swell from 81,000 units in 2003 to 106,000 in 2007.
llama3.2:1b: Humanoid robot Asimo has been improved to run, with the ability to make an accurate leap and absorb impact without slipping or spinning at 3km/h. It is four times as fast as Sony's Qrio and can walk faster than Olympic runner Kelly Holmes, but not quite as fast as the first robot to run last year.
llama3.2:3b: Honda's humanoid robot Asimo has improved its running ability, increasing speed by almost four times compared to Sony's Qrio, and can now also navigate obstacles and interact with people. The robot has increased walking speed, height, and weight, while gaining more freedom of movement. Asimo was inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame in November and is being developed for potential employment in homes and offices, with its advanced technology potentially applying to car design.
gemma2:2b: Honda's humanoid robot Asimo has gained the ability to run.  The robot can now run at a speed of 3 km/h, four times faster than the previous runner, Sony's Qrio. Asimo also boasts improved walking speed and freedom of movement. The robot has already been inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame and is being used as an ambassador for technological advancements by various tech firms.  The global market for industrial robots is expected to increase significantly in coming years.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Honduras' new humanoid robot, Asimo, can now run and walk better than Kelly Holmes’ Qrio robot. It is fast enough for a regular jog but not yet as fast as a professional athlete like the world's top athlete Usain Bolt. The robot has improved in other ways too, like growing taller, gaining weight, and bending its necks. Asimo can do some cool tricks, like climbing on high shelves or getting up from a chair, which people often find hard to believe!
qwen2.5:1.5b: Honda's humanoid robot Asimo has improved its running capabilities, becoming faster and more accurate, with a walking speed of up to 2.5 km/h. The robot can now run, interact with people, and walk upstairs as part of a quest for practical applications in daily life, such as homes and offices. It aims to be used by tech firms like Honda to promote technological advancements.
qwen2.5:3b: Honda's humanoid robot Asimo can now run, find its way around obstacles, and interact with people after improvements. Initially running at 3km/h (a leisurely jog), it is nearly four times faster than Sony's Qrio. Asimo has also improved in walking speed, height, weight, and flexibility. It has been recognized for its abilities by being inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame and attending a state dinner. Robots like Asimo have potential applications in automotive technology and are expected to play roles in society as entertainment and helpers in daily life.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to help summarize this text about a humanoid robot named Asimo developed by Honda and the Japanese company. The user provided some key points, so my goal is to create a concise summary that captures all the main ideas without too much detail.

First, I'll read through the text carefully to understand the flow of information. It starts with Asimo learning how to run at Honda, mentioning it's advanced and can navigate obstacles and interact with people. The Indonesian company's position as a leader in two-legged robots is noted. They aim for jobs in homes and offices.

Next, the technical aspects: Asimo improved speed from 1.6 km/h to 2.5 km/h, growing 10 cm in height and adding about 2 kg of weight. The criteria for running are feet off the ground between strides. It's also noted that it can do a leisurely jog at 3 km/h instead of Kelly Holmes' standard.

Then, Asimo has a reputation as an entertainer with a presence in the Robot Hall of Fame and attendance at a state dinner. There was controversy about its gait being comical. The text mentions robots now performing serious tasks and predicts a rise in industrial robot usage globally.

I need to condense this into a summary that highlights key points: Honda's role, Asimo's capabilities (speed, ability to interact, navigate obstacles), target applications in daily life and entertainment, its design criteria, technological implications for the automotive industry, current status in the robot community, and global market predictions.

I should ensure each key point is included without unnecessary details. The summary should be clear and flow logically from introduction to conclusions.
</think>

Honda developed a humanoid robot, Asimo, known as the "Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility." It excels in running, navigating obstacles, interacting with people, and can achieve leisurely jogs at 3 km/h. Its design criteria require feet off the ground between strides, improving speed from 1.6 km/h to 2.5 km/h (an increase of 10 cm) and weight gain of about 2 kg. Asimo has a niche role as an entertainer and has been inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame for its gait. It is used by tech firms, blending technology with entertainment. The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe predicts a rise in industrial robot usage from 81,000 units to 106,000 in four years.
tinyllama:1.1b: Humanoid robot Asimo is now able to run at a faster pace and has improved running speed by almost four times as much as Sony's Qrio robot. While it can run like an average human, it still needs to be controlled with precise movements and steps to avoid slipping or spinning. The improvement in speed is attributed to the robot's ability to absorb impact without slipping, making it a faster runner than before. Asimo has already made a mark on the international robot scene and was inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame in November 2017. Its appearance and physical features have won over audiences from various industries, including automobiles, which is now set to benefit with the development of electronic parts. Despite its shortcomings, Asimo's entertaining nature will keep it in demand as a toy or a tourist attraction until the technology becomes more advanced.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The humanoid robot Asimo of Honda has recently been given a new lease on life by being made faster and smarter by its Japanese company, Innovative Mobility Services (IMS). This improvement not only allows the robot to run but also interact with people, demonstrating that even as technology improves, there are still many practical applications for robots in our daily lives.

Asimo's running speed is almost four times faster than his previous record, which he set earlier this year. His improved capabilities include more freedom of movement and increased walking speed. The improvements in Asimo's capabilities not only boost his entertainment value but also enable him to aid people in their daily lives. This makes him a valuable asset not just for his entertainment value, but also for his potential to provide assistance to individuals with mobility issues or those who may be injured.

IMS claims that Asimo's capabilities are even greater than what could have been expected from Sony's Qrio robot, which became the world's fastest-running robot in 2004. The criteria for running robots is set by engineers, and as mentioned earlier, Asimo has improved in other ways too, increasing his walking speed to 2.5km from the previous rate of 1.6km/h.

Asimo already holds a place in the Robot Hall of Fame due to his impressive abilities to walk up stairs, recognize faces, and even come when called by his creators. He also trounced the state dinner hosted by Japan's prime minister, which was attended by the presence of several technology companies, including Google, Apple, and IBM. His popularity has led him to be used in various promotional activities by tech firms like Honda, demonstrating how robots can play a vital role in society.

In summary, Asimo's improvements have not only made him faster but also more capable in his field, enabling him to provide a valuable service and even assist people with mobility issues. This demonstrates the versatility of robots and highlights the many ways they can be utilized in our lives.

While it is not quite up to Olympic standards, it is four times as fast as Sony's Qrio. It can also perform tricks such as walking upstairs and interacting with people. Its makers claim that this technology could be used in the automobile industry. Asimo has been inducted into the Robot Hall of Fame and has already made an impact on international robotics.

It has already wowed audiences worldwide and attended a state dinner in the Czech Republic as a goodwill envoy. Asimo's biggest role is an entertainer but the technology it developed could be used in the automobile industry. The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe predicts a huge market for industrial robots worldwide.

Developments from Asimo could also be used in the automobile industry, marking Asimo as an entertainer and demonstrating the potential for robots to fulfill serious functions in society.

Running required precise movement and impact absorption, and Asimo is now faster than Sony's Qrio. Other improvements include increased walking speed, height, weight, and greater mobility in joints. Asimo has gained international recognition, including induction into the Robot Hall of Fame, and has been showcased globally, even attending a state dinner. Honda sees potential applications of Asimo’s technology in the automobile industry. While currently an entertainer, robots like Asimo are expected to play significant roles in society, with the industrial robot market projected to grow significantly.
stablelm2:1.6b: Honda's humanoid robot Asimo has become faster and smarter, learning how to run and interact with people. Asimo can now navigate obstacles and eventually find gainful employment in homes and offices. The goal is to develop a robot capable of assisting daily life tasks. Asimo has also improved in other ways such as increasing walking speed, growing by 5cm, and adding 2kg in weight. He has made an international impact with his ability to walk up stairs, recognize faces, and respond to commands. The technology developed for Asimo could be used in the automobile industry due to the shift towards electronics over mechanics in car design. granite3.1-dense:2b: Honda's humanoid robot, Asimo, has been upgraded with capabilities to run and navigate obstacles more effectively. This advanced model can now maintain a pace of approximately 3km/h, which is nearly four times faster than Sony's Qrio, the first robot to run. Asimo also demonstrates improved walking speed from 1.6km/h to 2.5km/h, expanded height to 130cm, and increased weight by 2kg. It features enhanced mobility, allowing twisting of hips and bending of fingers, thumbs, and the neck. Although it falls short of Olympic standards, Asimo's running capabilities mark significant progress in its development as a potentially practical tool for daily assistance in homes and offices. The robot has already showcased impressive abilities, such as walking upstairs, recognizing faces, and following commands, earning recognition at the Robot Hall of Fame. Its potential applications extend beyond entertainment, with experts predicting a growing market for industrial robots in the coming years.
